statement.p: List the elements of the following sets. If there is more than one element write them separated by commas.
Let S = \lbrace w,x,y,z\rbrace, T = \lbrace 0\rbrace
How many elements are in S\times T?
Determine S\times T
[Note: Enter your answer as a comma-separated list. Pairs should be denoted with parentheses.]

static.solution:
S = \lbrace w,x,y,z\rbrace
T = \lbrace 0\rbrace
The number of elements in a Cartesian product is simply N(A)\cdot N(B) for any sets A, B.
Thus, the number of elements in S\times T is
N(A)\cdot N(B) = 4\cdot 1 = 4
The Cartesian product A\times B is defined as the set of all ordered pairs whose first component is a member of A and whose second component is a member of B.
More formally, A\times B = \lbrace (a,b) \vert a\in A \textbf{ and } b\in B\rbrace
Thus, S\times T is
\lbrace (w,0),(x,0),(y,0),(z,0)\rbrace

statement.p: Let f(x) = x^{2}. Find each set.

static.solution: x^{2} is not one-to-one, you can not simply plug the endpoints of the interval into the function to get the endpoints of the answer. Instead, try graphing the function and shading on the x-axis the input set. Then use the graph to see which y-values you get out when you put those x's in. For instance, notice that 0 \in (-4, 5). Because f(0) = 0, you should have 0 \in f( (-4, 5)). Do you?

statement.p: For each of the following functions, f:\textbf{R}\longrightarrow\textbf{R} state whether they are one-to-one, onto, both or neither. Use the following key:

Consider the functions f(x) = \sqrt[7]{\frac{x}{4}} + 8, g(x) = -8 + 4 x^{7}, h(x) = \sqrt[7]{\frac{x}{4}} - 8, p(x) = \sqrt[7]{\frac{x - 8}{4}}, q(x) = 8 + 4 x^{7}, and r(x) = \sqrt[7]{\frac{x + 8}{4}}.
Which of these functions are inverses of each other?

li.p: p(x) and q(x)
g(x) and p(x)
f(x) and q(x)
h(x) and q(x)
g(x) and h(x)
q(x) and r(x)
g(x) and r(x)
f(x) and g(x)
No pairs of these functions are inverses of each other.

static.solution:
SOLUTION
One way we can check which functions are inverses is to make sure they satisfy the identities f \left( f^{-1}(x) \right)=x and f^{-1} \left( f(x) \right)=x. This will show that p(x) and q(x) and g(x) and r(x) are inverses of each other, while the other pairs of functions are not.
Let's consider p(x) and q(x). The composition \begin{aligned} p\left(q(x)\right) \amp = 8 + 4 \left(\sqrt[7]{ \frac{x - 8}{4}}\right)^{7} \\ \amp = 8 + 4 \left( \frac{x - 8}{4} \right) \\ \amp = 8 + (x-8) = x. \end{aligned} Also, \begin{aligned} q\left(p(x)\right) \amp = \sqrt[7]{\frac{\left( 8+4 x^{7} \right)-8}{4}} \\ \amp = \sqrt[7]{x^{7}} = x. \end{aligned} Thus these are inverses of one another. We can similarly show that g(x) and r(x) are inverses of each other.
However, the remaining pairs are not inverses. For example, if we consider q(x) and r(x), we have \begin{aligned} q\left(r(x)\right) \amp = 8 + 4 \left( \sqrt[7]{ \frac{x + 8}{4}} \right)^{7}\\ \amp = 8 + (x+8) = x + 16 \ne x. \end{aligned} Thus these functions are not inverses of each other.

Let C(x) be the statement "x has a cat", let D(x) be the statement "x has a dog" and let F(x) be the statement "xhas a ferret". a) A student in your class has a cat, a dog, and a ferret.

If A and B are invertible n\times n matrices, then the inverse of A+B is A^{-1}+B^{-1}.

solution.p: SOLUTION: False. For example, let A = I_n, and B = -I_n, then A+B = 0_n, which is not invertible.

statement.p: Solve for the matrix X if AX(D+B X)^{-1} = C. Assume that all matrices are n\times n and invertible as needed.

solution.p: SOLUTION: Note that \begin{align*} AX(D+BX)^{-1} = C \amp \Rightarrow AX = C(D+BX) = CD + CBX \\ \amp \Rightarrow AX - CBX = CD\\ \amp \Rightarrow (A-CB)X = CD \\ \amp \Rightarrow X = (A-CB)^{-1} CD. \end{align*}

Let A=\left[\begin{matrix} 1 \amp 3 \amp -8 \cr 0 \amp 1 \amp -3 \cr \end{matrix}\right], {\bf b}=\left[\begin{matrix} -1 \cr 3 \cr 1 \cr \end{matrix}\right], and {\bf c}=\left[\begin{matrix} 1 \cr 0 \cr \end{matrix}\right]. Define T({\bf x})=A{\bf x}.
Select true or false for each statement.

li.p: The vector {\bf c} is in the range of T
The vector {\bf b} is in the kernel of T

static.solution:
A{\bf b}=\left[\begin{matrix} 1 \amp 3 \amp -8 \cr 0 \amp 1 \amp -3 \cr \end{matrix}\right] \left[\begin{matrix} -1 \cr 3 \cr 1 \cr \end{matrix}\right]= \left[\begin{matrix} 0 \cr 0 \cr \end{matrix}\right], so {\bf b}\in \ker(T).
We row-reduce to determine a solution of A{\bf x}={\bf c}.
\left[\begin{matrix} 1 \amp 3 \amp -8 \amp 1 \cr 0 \amp 1 \amp -3 \amp 0 \cr \end{matrix}\right]\sim \left[\begin{matrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 1 \cr 0 \amp 1 \amp -3 \amp 0 \cr \end{matrix}\right].
Thus A \left[\begin{matrix} 1 \cr 0 \cr 0 \cr \end{matrix}\right] = {\bf c}, so {\bf c}\in range(T).

statement.p: Let T({\bf x})=A{\bf x} for the matrix A and

A=\left[\begin{array}{ccc} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1\cr 5 \amp -5 \amp 5\cr -7 \amp -4 \amp 15 \end{array}\right], {\bf b}=\left[\begin{array}{c}1\\2\\1\\\end{array}\right], and {\bf c}=\left[\begin{array}{c}0\\-5\\-4\\\end{array}\right].
Select true or false for each statement.

The vector \bf{b} is in the kernel of T.
???
True
False

The vector \bf{c} is in the range of T.
???
True
False

static.solution:
A{\bf b}=\left[\begin{array}{ccc} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1\cr 5 \amp -5 \amp 5\cr -7 \amp -4 \amp 15 \end{array}\right] \left[\begin{array}{c}1\\2\\1\\\end{array}\right]= \left[\begin{array}{c}0\\0\\0\\\end{array}\right] ={\bf 0}, so {\bf b}\in \ker(T).
Row-reduce to determine a solution of A{\bf x}={\bf c}.
\left[\begin{array}{cccc} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 0\cr 5 \amp -5 \amp 5 \amp -5\cr -7 \amp -4 \amp 15 \amp -4 \end{array}\right] \sim \left[\begin{array}{cccc} 1 \amp 0 \amp -1 \amp 0\cr 0 \amp 1 \amp -2 \amp 1\cr 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \amp 0 \end{array}\right].
or simply notice that \bf{c} is the second column of \bf{A}. Row reduction shows that the equation \bf{A}\bf{x}=\bf{c} has infinitely many solutions:
\bf{x} = \left[\begin{array}{c}0\\1\\0\\\end{array}\right] + t \left[\begin{array}{c}1\\2\\1\\\end{array}\right] for arbitrary t \in \mathbb{R},
and both approaches lead to the conclusion that
A \left[\begin{array}{c}0\\1\\0\\\end{array}\right] = {\bf c}.
Thus {\bf c}\in range(T).

Are the following statements true or false?

li.p: R^n has exactly one subspace of dimension m for each of m = 0,1,2,\ldots, n .

statement.p: Suppose that S_1 and S_2 are nonzero subspaces, with S_1 contained inside S_2, and suppose that dim(S_2) = 3.

(a) What are the possible dimensions of S_1?
?
1
2
3
1 or 2
1,2, or 3

(b) If S_1\neq S_2 then what are the possible dimensions of S_1?
?
1
2
3
1 or 2
1,2, or 3

static.solution:
(a) The dimension of S_1 cannot exceed the dimension of S_2 since S_1 is contained in S_2. S_1 is non-zero, and thus its dimension cannot be 0. Hence 1, 2, or 3 are the possible dimensions of S_1.
(b) If S_1 \ne S_2, then S_1 is properly contained in S_2, and the dimension of S_1 is strictly less than the dimension of S_2. Thus only 1 or 2 are possible dimensions of S_1 .

statement.p: Suppose that S_1 and S_2 are nonzero subspaces, with S_1 contained inside S_2, and suppose that dim(S_2) = 4

li.p: If \ S_1 \ne S_2, then what are the possible dimensions of S_1 ?
What are the possible dimensions of S_1?

static.solution:
S_1 cannot exceed the dimension of S_2, since S_1 is contained in S_2. S_1 us non-zero, and thus the its dimension cannot be zero. Hence the possible dimensions of S_1 are 1, 2, 3, and 4.
b) If S_1 \ne S_2, then S_1 is properly contained in S_2, and the dimension of S_1 is strictly less than the dimension of S_2. So the possible dimensions of S_1 are 1, 2, and 3.

The dimension of the row space of A is .
The dimension of the column space of A is .
The dimension of the null space of A is .

solution.p: The dimension of the row space is the number of nonzero rows in the echelon form, or 4 - 2 = 2. The dimension of the column space is the same as the dimension of the row space, and the dimension of the null space is 8 - 2 = 6.

statement.p: Are the following statements true or false?

li.p: R^n has exactly one subspace of dimension m for each of m = 0,1,2,\ldots, n .
Let m>n. Then U = {u_1, u_2,\ldots, u_m} in R^n can form a basis for R^n if the correct m-n vectors are removed from U.

statement.p: Let X be a finite dimensional vector space (X=\mathbf{R}^n, for example), let S,S_1,S_2\subseteq X be subspaces of X and let U,V\subseteq X be subsets of X.
Which of the following statements are true for every X and every possible choice of subspaces and subsets? Which are false for some X and some choice of subsets and subspaces?

A. If a set of vectors \(U\) spans a subspace \(S\), then zero or more vectors can be removed from \(U\) to create a basis for \(S\) (i.e. there is a set of vectors \(V\) with \(V\subseteq U\) which is a basis of \(S\)).

B. If a set of vectors \(U\) is linearly independent in a subspace \( S\) then zero or more vectors can be removed from \(U\) to create a basis for \(S\) (i.e. there is a set of vectors \(V\) with \(V\subseteq U\) which is a basis of \(S\)).

C. If a set of vectors \(U\) is linearly independent in a subspace \( S\) then zero or more vectors can be added to \(U\) to create a basis for \(S\) (i.e. there is a set of vectors \(V\) with \(U\subseteq V\) which is a basis of \(S\)).

D. If a set of vectors \(U\) spans a subspace \(S\), then zero or more vectors can be added to \(U\) to create a basis for \(S\) (i.e. there is a set of vectors \(V\) with \(U\subseteq V\) which i-s a basis of \(S\)).
E. If \( \ S = \text{span}\{u_1, u_2, u_3 \}\) then \(\text{dim}(S) = 3\) .

li.p: True. If \(U\) is linearly independent then \(U\) is a basis. Otherwise one of the vectors in \(U\) is a linear combination of the others, so you can remove this vector from \(U\), and the remaining vectors will still span \(S\). Continuing in this fashion you can remove vectors one-by-one until you obtain a minimal linearly independent subset of \(U\). This subset is a basis for \(S\). (This argument depends on the fact that the dimension of \(S\) is finite. It is finite because \(S\subseteq X\) and \(X\) is finite dimensonal. Infinite dimensional spaces are much trickier.)
False. If \(U\) does not span \(S\) then no subset of \(U\) can span \(S\) so no subset of \(U\) is a basis for \(S\).

True. If \(U\) spans \(S\) then \(U\) is a basis for \(S\). Otherwise \(S\) contains a vector that is not in the span of \(U\). If you include that vector in \(U\) you'll get a larger set that is still linearly independent. Repeating this process you'll get larger and larger sets of linearly independent vectors until the number of vectors in the set equals the dimension of \(S\). When that happens the set of vectors will be a basis for \(S\). (That it's a basis isn't obvious but it's proved in linear algebra texts. The fact that \(S\) is finite-dimensional is crucial. It is finite dimensonal because \(S\subseteq X\) and \(X\) is finite dimensional. Infinite dimensonal spaces are much trickier).
False. If the vectors in \(U\) are not linearly independent then \(U\) cannot be a subset of a basis.
False. The vectors (1,0), (0,1), and (1,1) span the \(x,y\)-plane, but the \(x,y\)-plane is 2-dimensional. These vectors are not linearly independent.

p.me: L(x) = \left[\begin{array}{c} 25 x_1 + 4 x_2 - 25 x_3\\ 2 x_2\\ 75 x_1 - 75 x_3 \end{array}\right]

statement.p: (a) Find the dimension of the range of L:
(b) Find the dimension of the kernel of L:
(c) Let S be the subspace of \mathbb{R}^3 spanned by -16 e_1 and 6 e_2 + 6 e_3. Find the dimension of L(S):

solution.p: Solution: (a) Since e_1, e_2, e_3 spans \mathbb{R}^3, we get that L(\mathbb{R}^3) is spanned by L(e_1), L(e_2), L(e_3). So
and hence the dimension of the range is 2.
(b) The rank-nullity theorem implies that the dimension of the kernel is 3-2 = 1.
(c) Notice that L(S) = \mbox{span}\left(L(-16 e_1), L(6 e_2 + 6 e_3)\right) = \mbox{span}\left(L(e_1), L(e_2)+L(e_3)\right)
and it is easy to check that these two vectors are linearly independent. Therefore, the dimension of L(S) is 2.

(b) Find the equation of the plane that passes through the points P = (2,0,-5), Q = (-5,1,-2), and R = (1,-2,2). Write your answer in terms of the variables x, y, z.

solution.p: Solution: (a) The idea is to find a convenient point lying in the given plane. For example, let us pick P_1 = (1,0,1), and let \mathbf{v} be the vector from P_1 to P_0. Then the distance from P_0 to the plane is the absolute value of the scalar projection of \mathbf{v} onto the normal vector
So, we get that the distance is \frac{13}{\sqrt{69}}.

(b) To find an equation of the plane in question, we can work with the point P and the normal vector \mathbf{N} given by the cross product of the vector from P to Q, and the vector from P to R. It turns out that
So, an equation of the plane is -13 x - 46 y - 15 z= 49.

Find the least-squares solution \vec{x}^* of the system \left[\begin{array}{cc} 1 \amp 0\cr 0 \amp 1\cr 0 \amp 0 \end{array}\right] \vec{x} = \left[\begin{array}{c} 4\cr 5\cr 9 \end{array}\right].
By using the method of least squares, find the best line through the points:
Step 1. The general equation of a line is c_0 + c_1x = y. Plugging the data points into this formula gives a matrix equation \mathrm{A}\mathbf{c} = \mathbf{y}.
Step 2. The matrix equation \mathrm{A}\mathbf{c} = \mathbf{y} has no solution, so instead we use the normal equation \mathrm{A^T} \mathrm{A}\, \hat{\mathbf{c}} = \mathrm{A^T} \mathbf{y}
Step 3. Solving the normal equation gives the answer
which corresponds to the formula
Analysis. Compute the predicted y values: \hat{\mathbf{y}} = \mathrm{A}\hat{\mathbf{c}}.
Compute the error vector: \mathbf{e} = \mathbf{y} - \hat{\mathbf{y}}.
Compute the total error: \mathrm{SSE} = e_1^2+e_2^2+e_3^2.
By using the method of least squares, find the best parabola through the points:

Step 2. The matrix equation \mathrm{A}\mathbf{c} = \mathbf{y} has no solution, so instead we use the normal equation \mathrm{A^T} \mathrm{A}\, \hat{\mathbf{c}} = \mathrm{A^T} \mathbf{y}
